context: The Estonian verb 'lõigata' means to cut, slice, chop or trim something. It's a transitive verb that requires an object - you need to specify what is being cut. The word can be used for cutting various materials like food (bread), wood, paper, metal chains, etc. In different tenses and conjugations it appears as lõigan (I cut), lõigad (you cut), lõigab (he/she/it cuts), lõigame (we cut), lõigate (you plural/formal cut), and lõivad (they cut).
